chapter.title: Session 1: overview and learning objectives
chapter.content:
Welcome to Session 1: Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA) and Workforce Preparation. This session will introduce the workforce preparation activities referenced in WIOA section 203, which help adult education programs meet the goal of improving access to education and training opportunities, as well as to employment for all adults.

After completing this session, you will be able to:

  • explain the importance of workforce preparation activities in achieving WIOA outcomes;
  • define workforce preparation activities; 
  • describe the evidence that illustrates how workforce preparation activities align with and reinforce effective teaching strategies for deeper learning; and
  • match sample lesson activities with the specific workforce preparation skills they illustrate.

chapter.title: Six core programs integral to the workforce development system
chapter.content:
Why are workforce preparation activities so important? Under WIOA, adult education is identified as one of six core programs of the workforce development system (WIOA, 2015. Title II). Adult education’s role is to provide critical services and activities to support adult learners with the goal of improving access to education and training opportunities, as well as to employment (OCTAE, 2015).

The legislation outlines a vision for an array of education and workforce services, coordinated across the six core programs. WIOA promotes educational delivery models and activities such as:

    • Career Pathways;

    • Integrated Education and Training;

    • Integrated English Literacy and Civics Education.

The descriptions of each of these services and programs reference workforce preparation activities as a component.

Six Core Programs

Six core programs are:

    • adult, dislocated worker, and youth  programs administered by the Department of Labor
    • adult education programs funded through the Adult and Family Literacy Act, administered by the Department of Education
    • employment services funded through the Wagner-Peyser Act and administered by the Department of Labor
    • vocational rehabilitation programs funded through the Rehabilitation Act, administered by the Department of Education

chapter.title: Shared accountability through performance indicators
chapter.content:
WIOA also organizes a system of shared accountability across the six core programs through joint performance indicators. These performance indicators include:

  • employment rate the 2nd and 4th quarter after participants exit a program;
  • median earnings;
  • credential attainment;
  • measurable skill gain; and
  • effectiveness in serving employers.

 

Continue to Introducing Workforce Preparation Activities.

chapter.title: Meeting the needs of individuals with barriers to employment
chapter.content:
WIOA requires all six core programs to develop services and strategies to meet the needs of the most vulnerable in our communities, such as low-income adults and youth with limited skills and work experiences.

Learners with barriers to employment benefit from engaging in workforce preparation activities through:

  • improved academic and/or English language skills
  • increased ability to transfer skills from the classroom to the workplace

Workforce preparation activities provide a renewed emphasis on employment and postsecondary education and training in academic skill instruction.

Review the list below, of the 14 populations with barriers to employment outlined in Section 3 of WIOA.

Populations with Barriers to Employment 

WIOA provides a new and expanded definition for individuals with a barrier to employment. The term refers to any individual who is a member of one or more of the following populations:

    • Displaced homemakers
    • Low-income individuals
    • American Indians, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians (as defined in section 166)
    • Individuals with disabilities, including youth who are individuals with disabilities
    • Older individuals
    • Ex-offenders
    • Homeless individuals, homeless children or youth
    • Youth who are in or have aged out of the foster care system
    • Individuals who are English language learners, individuals who have low levels of literacy, and individuals facing substantial cultural barriers
    • Eligible migrant and seasonal farmworkers
    • Individuals within two years of exhausting lifetime eligibility of Social Security Part A
    • Single parents (including single pregnant women)
    • Long-term unemployed individuals
    • Such other groups as the governor involved determines to have barriers to employment
